awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Root-to-Shoot Communication via the bps Signal
awd_abstract_narration:
Drought causes dramatic reductions in agricultural yields.  An important step toward mitigating drought-associated losses is to fully understand how perception of drought causes reduced growth, and its associated impacts on agricultural production.  The earliest perception of drought occurs as roots encounter dry soil, and the resulting whole-plant responses are believed to arise from a mobile chemical signal that moves from roots to shoots. The Sieburth lab has discovered a highly conserved gene family that regulates production of a root-to-shoot signal that is sufficient to induce drought responses.  The goal of this research is to identify this signaling molecule.  The Sieburth and Dilkes labs will use metabolomic, genetic, and gene expression based approaches.  This combination of strategies should chemically identify the mobile signal and establish its relationship to other known components of root-to-shoot signaling.  Knowing the chemical identity of the root-to-shoot signal could lead to development of new agricultural practices that promote greater food security.

Plants drought responses include synthesis of abscisic acid (ABA) in the shoots, and decreased growth rates.  Because most drought responses are measured in shoots, whereas the plant root is believed to initially detect drought conditions, scientists have long postulated a mobile root-to-shoot chemical signal that coordinates drought responses.  The bypass1 (bps1) mutant of Arabidopsis has a growth-arrest phenotype caused by a graft-transmissible signal over-produced in bps1 roots.  Transcriptomics and hormone measurements demonstrated that this mobile compound is sufficient to induce ABA synthesis in wild-type shoots, and genetic analyses demonstrated that growth arrest is independent of ABA.  This project's goal is chemical identification of this over-produced compound. Experiments will use previously established extraction methods, fractionation by Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography, and analysis by mass spec.  Other experiments will use a labeled precursor and precursor analogs; these will clarify the structural components of the precursor that are required in the active product, and time-resolved assays using the labeled precursor should prove informative for its biosynthetic pathway.  In addition, bps1 and wild type root transcriptomes will be compared, and reverse genetic analyses will be carried out to test whether differentially expressed genes are necessary to produce the mobile compound.  Finally, bps1 mutants will be generated in another plant species, and its metabolome analyzed; this experiment will test the hypothesis that this drought-induced root-to-shoot compound is the same in different plant species.  Diverse undergraduates and high-school students will be trained through this grant; broad outreach to under-represented groups includes interaction with local community colleges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plant growth is controlled by mobile signals that are made in one organ and cause coordinated growth in another. Many of these signals are known, but the chemicals responsible for some events in plant adaptation and growth coordination are unknown. Many of known plant growth coordinating signals were identified by bioassays, in which extracted metabolites from a plant generating the signal were applied to plants that can receive the signal. Other signals have only recently been identified through discoveries assisted by the phenotypes of mutants that show disrupted growth or environmental responses. One such mutant is the bypass1 mutant which results in a root-derived signal that arrests shoot growth. This mutant and root-to-shoot growth-arresting activity was discovered by the Sieburth lab at the University of Utah. Growth arrest in the shoot affected by a root-derived signal strongly resembles the coordination of shoot growth during droughts. The signal produced in bypass1 results in accumulation for the drought related plant growth regulator ABA in shoots but genetic experiments demonstrate that ABA is not responsible for shoot growth arrest. This collaborative project between the Dilkes and Sieburth labs sought to test likely candidates for this mobile signal, characterize the response of shoots to the signal, and to purify and test by bioassay root-derived metabolites to better characterize the mobile signal that is overproduced in these mutants.

One challenge to identifying the signal has been the small amount of tissue, and therefore signaling molecule, available in a growth arrested Arabidopsis seedling. To overcome this, growth recovery was identified in crosses between bypass1 and some ecotypes of Arabidopsis. On in particular, Apost-1, resulted in dwarfed but fertile bypass1 mutants. A single locus (monogenic additive QTL) from Apost-1 was sufficient to affect growth recovery affected in bypass1 homozygotes. Molecular identification of the gene responsible for this identified that it was encoded by one of the other genes in the Arabidopsis genome that was highly similar to bypass1, demonstrating functional redundancy of the genes in this family. Phylogenetic analysis across plants demonstrates the conservation of bypass1-homologs as members of a larger family of plant-specific proteins encoding multiple domains of unknown function. The bypass1 mutant plants with the growth rescuing Apost-1 allele still overproduce a growth arresting signal , as evidenced by bioassays. This genetically defined material was grown in large quantities and used to purify the signal overproduced in bypass1 mutants and identify it. 

Bioassays of shoot and root growth arrest following application of extracts from bypass1 mutants demonstrated accumulation of the bypass signal in the APOST-rescued bypass1 mutants. This allowed us to extract metabolites from much larger volumes of starting material and separate the metabolites by high pressure liquid chromatography. Bioassays of fractions of these separated metabolites were bioassayed following multiple chromatographic approaches. By collecting samples for bioassay and analyzing them by Mass Spectroscopy, in parallel, we were able to identify components that co-chromatographed with the growth-arresting activity. Single dimension MS and two-dimensional MS-MS identified a number of structurally related co-chromatographing compounds within the bioactive-fractions.

Some signaling molecules are known to move from roots to shoot, including CLAVATA-LIKE (CLE) peptides. One such peptide, CLE25, also activates similar gene expression and hormone signaling events as the bypass1 signal. The Sieburth lab tested this candidate for the bypass1 signal genetically and demonstrated that loss of the CLE25 receptors did not restore plant growth indicating that the CLE25 signal cannot be the cause of root-to-shoot transmissible growth arrest in the bypass1 mutants.

Broader Impacts

Understanding how plants coordinate growth is required for us to usnerstand the constraints and causes of the plant forms, distribution of plants on the landscape, their responses to change, and adaptation to the environment. In particular, the mechanism by which roots signal growth arrest on the shoot is of critical relevance to abiotic stress adaptation of crops to conditions of water limitation and could result in transformative technological developments in agriculture. This project resulted in workforce development including two graduate students, a postdoctoral researcher, and an undergraduate researcher. Team members developed skills in bioinformatics, mutant genetic screening, genomics, metabolite profiling, biochemistry, and quantitative and population genetics
